title.narrative: CO-Fair Finance Asia - Sida - Vietnam Pr

description.narrative:
The Fair Finance Asia Program (FFA) envisages to reduce the negative impact of national and cross-border bank investments in Asia on human rights, the environment and climate change, and to increase adequate financial services for pro-poor, inclusive economic development. The goal is to establish a sustainable financial sector in Asia, with financial sector institutions operating at national and regional level being more transparent and accountable and adhering to Economic, Social and Governance (ESG)-criteria. FFA is funded by Sida.
This project is implemented by Oxfam in Vietnam. It envisages to contribute to FFA by promoting environmental and social responsibility of commercial banks who are investing environmentally and socially sensitive projectssuch as coal power. They prioritize the energy sector, since this makes up the majority of regional loans to Vietnam and has the largest environmental impacts. In this project, the FFG coalition of Oxfam and partners in Vietnam will adopt the Fair FinanceGuide (FFG) to assess investment policies of Vietnamese and foreign banks investing in the coal power sector and do an in-depth study to assess environmental performance of some selected commercial banks. When investigating Vietnamese and foreign banks investing in coal power sectors, the Vietnamese coalition will specifically target Japanese banks, which are the 2nd largest investors in coal power plants in Vietnam: JBIC, Mitsubishi (MUFG), Mizuho, Sumitomo Mitsui (SMBC). Later they will also extend advocacy on coal power to banks from Vietnam, China, and other countries to the extent this is possible within the scope of FFA. Another focus is on Vietnamese banks investing in cross-border projects on hydropower, agriculture, and other issues: Vietinbank,others. Regionally, the Vietnamese coalition will join with Thailand and other countries targeting regional banks investing in hydropower (i.e. the six Thai banks funding the Xayaburi dam in Laos: Bankgok Bank, Kasikorn Bank, Krung Thai Bank, Siam Commercial Bank, TISCO, and EXIM bank).

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

Improved policies Governments and global actors: # cases (sub)national governments or global actors adopting and/or implementing improved gender sensitive policies on promotion of a transparent, accountable and inclusive financial sector.
pieces of evidence (documents, studies, videos, testimonies etc.) produced by Oxfam Novib and partners in support of development/adoption of alternative policies/approaches

comment.narrative:
The consultation workshop on the direct lending to SMEs model of SMEs Fund was organized on 14 January 2021 by the Small and Medium Enterprise Development Fund (SMEDF) with the participation of one representative from FFV. The FFV member raised the topicon gender responsive in funding and ESG compliance as they are not considered as main topics.
One annotated of FFV’s list of publication in English and in Vietnamese (see Annex 3) was sent to 137 recipients.
One Policy brief titled ‘Towards Sustainable Finance’ summarizes 10 Vietnamese commercial banks' scores on their ESG policy commitments. FFV provides recommendations to these banks and the State bank of Vietnam to promote the performance of such commitments to align with international standards. The policy brief is published on FFA’s website in both English and Vietnamese.

comment.narrative: Two ethnic women from Ban Ho, Lao Cai province where one case study was conducted attended and raised their opinions on the impact of hydropower in their communities at the launch workshop on 20 April 2021. At grass root level, one woman, four men from local authorities and tourist company raised their opinions and concerns on the development of hydropower plant in Long Dai river, Quang Binh province.

comment.narrative: 3 national coalitions - OiV, WARECOD, HaUI attended FFA's training, learning events (five learning events such as UN RBHR side session - Are financial institutions reliable accelerators of labour and human rights practices in Asia's agriculture sector? -organized by Fair Finance Asia and Grow Asia; Banking on Women’s Empowerment in the ASEAN Agricultural Sector; Taxonomy; Introduction of Outcomes Harvesting; Mid-term review and management response) 58 CSOs received training provided by FFV

description.narrative: Stronger and wider alliances: # strengthened alliances on financial sector research, on transparent, accountable and inclusive financial sector, on integration of ESG & Human Rights criteria and/or promote financial inclusion of people living in poverty.
cases in which Oxfam Novib and partners supported joint agendas of networks, alliances

comment.narrative: • Led by Bank Track, on 1 March 2021, FFV singed the letter that aims to respond to the argument that HSBC is making which is that 'coal is good for development' • On 22 Jan, FFV joined with FFI and FFJ to sign one petition to call upon the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) to reverse its decision to provide financing for the Vung Ang 2 coal-fired power plant project in Vietnam. (See 2.3.a) - OiV provided comments to Recourse’s research on the IMF’s policy advice and its impact upon countries’ climate change commitments in respect of financial and banking sector and climate changes in Vietnam, which were integrated into the final report

description.narrative: stakeholder sessions organized by Oxfam Novib and partners

comment.narrative: '- CSO-prep meeting on understanding Independent Accountability Mechanisms (IAMs) of DFIs - ‘Vietnam Virtual Outreach Workshop on Access to Recourse in Development Projects through Independent Accountability Mechanisms’ - Five bilateral meetings with the FFV coalition members - One launch workshop of Bank policies assessment and case studies - One virtual dialogue on ‘River ecosystem, communities and development of hydropower’ - One meeting between FFV and BIDV Training and Research Institute and Banking Strategic Institute - One meeting between FFV and the advisory group members - One consultation workshop with state bank, commercial banks, professionals in banking and financial sector to provide feedback to findings of two studies
